abstract: The owners of The Evening Standard announced that it would be sold to a Russian tycoon, Aleksandr Y. Lebedev, a former K.G.B. agent.
snippet: The owners of The Evening Standard announced that it would be sold to a Russian tycoon, Aleksandr Y. Lebedev, a former K.G.B. agent.
lead_paragraph: PARIS  He had been one of the K.G.B.’s men in London, a spy who rose swiftly through the ranks. Yet, when Soviet Communism collapsed, he switched seamlessly to its ideological rival as a banker worth billions in the free-wheeling capitalism of the new Russia. Some British newspapers took to calling him the spy who came in for the gold.

byline.original: By Alan Cowell and Eric Pfanner

abstract: The owner of London’s Evening Standard said Wednesday it has agreed to sell a majority stake in the newspaper to Aleksandr Lebedev, the Russian tycoon and former KGB spy, for what it described as “a nominal sum.”
lead_paragraph: The owner of London’s Evening Standard said Wednesday it has agreed to sell a majority stake in the newspaper to Aleksandr Lebedev, the Russian tycoon and former KGB spy, for what it described as “a nominal sum.”

headline.main: Ex-KGB Spy Buys London’s Evening Standard
